Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Linking climate-driven changes in erosion to tectonic processes along the southern Alaska Margin
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most challenging questions in active mountain building is how climate might drive tectonic processes, in the form of mass redistribution. In other words, do climate-driven changes in erosion lead to increased exposure of mountainous belts, and perhaps influence tectonic processes, like uplift and faulting, as predicted by numerical models? The study of this question, by means of observational and analytical data is challenging because most areas where active mountain building is occurring are covered by remnant glaciers and glaciated landscapes from the end of the Neogene period (23 ? 2.5 million years ago). The St. Elias mountain belt, in southeast Alaska, is a prime location to address this question due to its extensive glaciation. The recent erosional record of this active mountain range is stored in the Gulf of Alaska and was recovered during Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Expedition 341. Integrated analysis of deep-sea core material obtained from drilling at the continental shelf, slope, and the deep-sea Surveyor Fan will provide means to quantify the effect of global and local climate changes on the erosional and structural evolution of a mountain range. The youthfulness of the St. Elias belt, along with high rates of tectonic and erosional processes, and its close proximity of the Gulf of Alaska provide an ideal natural setting to study climate-tectonic interactions.

Long-standing debates exist in the Earth sciences on whether Neogene climate change affects rates of surface processes, such as erosion, and consequently influences tectonic processes, such as faulting, through redistribution of mass. The proposed study will test the hypothesis that an increase in glacial erosion has led to focused exhumation in the core of the St. Elias orogeny as proposed by numerical and analytical data. Two possible target regions have been suggested where a tectonic-climate feedback may have developed: in the fold-thrust belt and at the indenting Yakutat plate corner. The wealth of existing onshore geo- and thermochronological data provide a comprehensive picture of the current spatial pattern of exhumation rates, but the quantification of changes in rates and patterns through time has been challenging. The research team?s approach is to investigate the offshore sedimentary record of the St. Elias orogeny deposited in the Gulf of Alaska. This orogeny developed during a period of significant global climate change, including the intensification of Northern Hemisphere glaciation (iNHG) at the Plio-Pleistogene transition (PPT), ~2.6 Ma, and the mid-Pleistocene transition (MPT) from 1.2 to 0.7 Ma, but also a change of local climate resulting in alpine glaciers, perhaps as early as the Late Miocene/Pliocene (6.5 Ma). The high-resolution magnetostratigraphic and biostratigraphic age control from the IODP Expedition 341 cores allow close linking of changes in sedimentary lithofacies and textures, provenanace, exhumation, and sediment routing and distribution, to test the record of climate-tectonic interactions along the southern Alaska margin. The integration of Gulf of Alaska seismic reflection data with the age and provenance control from the 341 cores allow examination of sediment mass flux in the regional offshore depositional system, the Surveyor Fan, from a 3-D perspective through time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plate tectonics and mountain building interact with surface processes that erase mountains through weathering and erosion. The St. Elias Mountains in Southeast Alaska are an excellent natural laboratory to observe this interaction because tectonics and erosion processes are both strong and likely to be detectable in the geologic record.

Surface processes in the St. Elias Mountains are primarily glacial. North America’s largest ice fields and glaciers—such as the Bagley-Bering Glacier, Hubbard Glacier, and Seward-Malaspina Glacier—cover the St. Elias Mountains and efficiently transport the eroded sediment directly into the Gulf of Alaska.

This project investigated the glacial sediment deposited in the Gulf of Alaska and recovered by IODP drilling expedition 341. These sediments were deposited over the past 10 million years and thus archive the history of tectonic–surface process interactions.

We utilized multiple dating techniques on individual mineral grains that were separated from the sediment core samples. We used fission-track dating on apatite and zircon grains, which revealed the time and pace of exhumation in the upper crust and is a measure of the interaction between tectonic uplift and erosion in the sediment source region. The zircon grains were also analyzed for their U-Pb age, which refers to the mineral crystallization and rock formation, thus enabling the identification of each grain’s specific source region on land.

Our data from boreholes located south of the Bering Glacier on the continental shelf, slope, and the proximal deep sea all show the same age distributions. This result implies that the Bagley-Bering Glacier sourced all of the material deposited at these locations since at least 1 million years ago, and that lateral sediment mixing is very limited. Integrating the dating results with seismic mapping of submarine channels and structures reveals that the tectonic development of the fold-thrust belt creates submarine barriers that prevent lateral sediment transport. The data prove that the current drainage divide between the Seward and Bagley Ice field, located near the highest peaks in the mountain range, must have been stable over the past one million years because the rapid cooling signal from underneath the Seward Glacier is not present in the analyzed offshore deposits in front of Bering Glacier.

Another important result of this study is the overwhelming tectonic control on orogeny. We show that strong surface processes can amplify exhumation and rock deformation within the mountain range, leading to exceptionally rapid rates of cooling if they spatially coincide with tectonic uplift. However, we do not see evidence that the strong erosion from the Bagley-Bering Glacier lead to increased uplift that would result in extreme rapid rock exhumation.

This study investigated the distal deep-sea deposits, which reveal extreme rapid exhumation and imply that a strong tectonic-erosion interaction had already developed by 12–10 Ma. This finding implies that strong tectonic-erosion feedback mechanisms do not require erosion by glaciers, but can also develop in strong river systems.

One graduate student and three undergraduate students were involved with this project through training in a large variety of analytical measurements, data interpretation and the presentation of data at international conferences. All students successfully graduated and the master’s thesis was published in a peer reviewed scientific journal.
